markov
Class HiddenMarkovModel

java.lang.Object
  markov.HiddenMarkovModel

public class HiddenMarkovModel
extends java.lang.Object

HMM with normal distribution emission density for each feature vector component within each state

Constructor Summary
HiddenMarkovModel(int n)
          Constructor method to create an HMM object with n states and initialise the required arrays
HiddenMarkovModel(int n, java.util.ArrayList<double[][]> dataList, java.util.ArrayList<int[]> labelsList)
          Constructor method to train an HMM using sequence data and given the corresponding data labels, dataList is a list of arrays of size [featureDimension][lengthSequence] storing the MFCC feature vectors for each time segment in each example, labelsList is a list of arrays of size [lengthSequence] storing the corresponding state sequence
HiddenMarkovModel(int n, double[][] transitions, Normal[][] emissions)
          Constructor method to build an HMM given known transition and emission probabilities
 
Method Summary
 java.math.BigDecimal forward(double[][] dataSequence)
          Forward algorithm - see equation (11) in Section 4.2 of the notes, Input is dataSequence[featureDimension][sequenceLength], Output is the probability of the data sequence under the model
 Normal getEmissionDensity(int feature, int state)
          Method for getting the emission probability distribution for a particular feature and state
 int getNoStates()
          Method returning the number of states (excluding START/STOP states)
 double getTransitionProbability(int i, int j)
          Method for getting the transition probabilities from state i to state j, i,j = 0 to noStates-1 for standard states, i,j = noStates for START/STOP states
 void setEmissionDensity(Normal density, int feature, int state)
          Method for setting the emission probability distribution for a particular feature and state
 void setTransitionProbability(double probability, int i, int j)
          Method for setting the transition probabilities from state i to state j, i,j = 0 to noStates-1 for standard states, i,j = noStates for START/STOP states
 int[] viterbi(double[][] dataSequence)
          Viterbi algorithm returns the optimal path through the hidden states for an input data sequence: Input is dataSequence[featureDimension][sequenceLength], Output is the inferred most likely path through the hidden states as an array of ints
 
Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object
clone, equals, finalize, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

viterbi

public int[] viterbi(double[][] dataSequence)
Viterbi algorithm returns the optimal path through the hidden states for an input data sequence: Input is dataSequence[featureDimension][sequenceLength], Output is the inferred most likely path through the hidden states as an array of ints
